awd_titl_txt: Increasing the Number and Diversity of Cybersecurity Technicians in Rural North Carolina
awd_abstract_narration:
The US Bureau of Labor Statistics projects that the need for cybersecurity technicians will grow more than 30 percent over the next decade. The number of students enrolled in and graduating from cybersecurity programs is not at a pace that can meet this growing demand. As a result, the nation will not have enough domestically trained cybersecurity technicians to satisfy the needs of industry, business, government, and other sectors. This project aims to addresses critical regional and national needs for skilled cybersecurity technicians.  It will do so by collaborating with the local education agency’s high school Career and Technical Education program, local businesses, and industries to increase the number of trained cybersecurity technicians who are ready for work. Program pathways will be created that allow students to earn credits toward a degree in applied science while completing an industry-recognized certificate in cybersecurity. Internships with local businesses and organizations will provide students with opportunities to put the skills they are learning in the classroom into real-world practice.

The goals of this project include: (1) producing skilled, highly qualified, and career-ready cybersecurity technicians; (2) equipping information technology faculty with the cybersecurity knowledge and skills required to effectively teach cybersecurity and optimize student learning and retention; (3) recruiting, retaining, and graduating individuals from communities that are underrepresented in cybersecurity, including women. Evaluation of the project will include both formative and summative assessment of the efficacy of the program in meeting the proposed goals and outcomes. The outcomes of this project have the potential to advance knowledge about challenges that students in a rural community face as learners in STEM fields, particularly in the information technology and cybersecurity fields.  This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
NSF ATE OUTCOMES REPORT

Robeson Community College

The Robeson Community College Increasing the Number and Diversity of Cybersecurity Technicians in Rural North Carolina Scholars initiative was funded with a National Science Foundation grant for $299,792.00 that focused on the following three goals: Goal 1: Address the region’s and nation’s critical cybersecurity workforce through shortage of qualified cybersecurity technicians. Goal 2: Equip Information Technology faculty with opportunities to gain specific cybersecurity knowledge and skills to increase effectiveness on course delivery that will optimize student learning and retention. Goal 3: Recruit, retain, graduate, and cybersecurity workforce advancement for females and underserved groups.

This project's overarching goal was to address critical regional and national needs for skilled cybersecurity technicians. This was accomplished through collaborations with the local education agency’s high schools, Career and Technical Education program, local businesses, and industries to increase the number of trained cybersecurity technicians ready for work. The project's success can be noted in its development of internships with local companies and organizations that provided students with opportunities to put the skills they learned in the classroom into real-world practice. The program expanded its program to include providing apprenticeship opportunities for the participants, through the North Carolina Community College Apprenticeship Program. Additionally, program pathways were created that allowed students to earn credits toward a degree in applied science while completing an industry-recognized certificate in cybersecurity.

The project efforts also addressed the underrepresentation of females and minorities in the cybersecurity field, and this was reflected by the increase in the number of females participating as well as their representation from the ethnic groups such as African American, and Caucasian. Hispanic, Multi-racial, and Native American. The project made substantial progress with student recruitment, course enrollment, and achieving demographic goals. During grant year one, the fall/spring program supported 33 students, and the fall/spring year two program supported 31 students. During the final year three, fall/spring the program supported 27 students. Female enrollment was impacted with year one experiencing an increase in enrollment by 5 females, with grant year two increasing to 11 female students and during the final grant year three the number increased by 14 female students, thus showing substantial growth.

STEM capacity building was impacted by the project providing opportunities for the project management (PI & Co-PI) to participate in professional development that resulted in the completion of certifications that include Cisco Certified Support Technician Cybersecurity, CCNAv7 Introduction to Network, and the PI receiving the Cisco Networking Academy Instructor Excellence Award. Project management was also provided the opportunity to give presentations at regional and national conferences. Noteworthy, support of economically disadvantaged students in Robeson County with their STEM education, was fulfilled by the project providing summer camps for local middle and high school students and educational workshops for public school educators. 

 


Last Modified: 05/30/2024
Modified by: Michael L Jacobs
